thread.title: This Instagram Star Posted a Makeup-Free Selfie to Make a Powerful Point About Self-Acceptance
thread.title_full: This Instagram Star Posted a Makeup-Free Selfie to Make a Powerful Point About Self-Acceptance

author: Cosmopolitan.com
title: This Instagram Star Posted a Makeup-Free Selfie to Make a Powerful Point About Self-Acceptance
text:
Carys Gray ( @busybeefitness ) is a 20-year-old student from Wales with more than 131,000 Instagram followers. She often posts selfies of herself working out or modeling cute fitness clothing:
100,000 followers!!!‚≠êÔ∏è Wow I really want to take this time to thank you so so much for all of your love, support, comments and help over the last 9 months since starting my account. üíó I absolutely LOVE having this account and doing what I'm doing and it would not be possible without you guys. üíó I love reading every comment and message and always try and respond to everyone, I get upset when I can't get around to replying to them allüòûüòû but please know that I always read them and appreciate them so much. ‚ù§Ô∏è Thank you for your constant support and for this amazing community we have which never fails to overwhelm me üò© You guys are seriously da best! Here's to the next 9 months and whatever the future may bring üôåüèº ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è Ps: I hope you'll all continue to be by my side in the future cus u better not be leaving me anytime soon cus I got a the feels and emotional attachments to u all so plz stay ily ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è #fitness #fit #health #healthy #gym #workout #Abs #glutes #fitfam #girlswholift #cardio #fitspo #instafit #gains #girlgains #muscle #strength #motivation #muslce #booty #leanin15 #gymshark #gymsharkwomen #womensbest
A post shared by Carys Gray || Cardiff, UKüá¨üáß (@busybeefitness) on Feb 6, 2017 at 8:42am PST
Advertisement - Continue Reading Below But on Wednesday, Carys posted a photo revealing a very different side of her.
"Slightly different #REALITYCHECK today," she wrote in the caption. "Social media/Instagram will show the good days, the good parts of people and their lives ‚Äî and that's OK! That's what social media is for! But here's a reminder that next time you see something on social media that you think is 'goals' that it's not the full story, it's not how that person will look or be a the time....I'm still struggling to accept myself on the right..."
Slightly different #REALITYCHECK today! ‚ÄºÔ∏è We all have good days and we all have bad daysüòû I have a skin condition called eczema and sometimes my skin is happy as Larry and sometimes it has flare upsüòü ‚ÄºÔ∏è Social media/Instagram will show the good days. The good parts of people and their lives and that's ok!! That's what social media is for! ‚ÄºÔ∏è But here's a reminder that next time you see something on social media that you think is 'goals' that it's not the full story, it's not how that person will look or be a the time! üôÖüèº I'm still struggling to accept myself on the right, it's a big insecurity of mine and that's fine. I'm learning to accept myself knowing that everyone has their own struggles and insecurities and that's what makes us unique and special ü§ó #fitness #fit #health #healthy #gym #workout #Abs #glutes #fitfam #girlswholift #cardio #fitspo #instafit #gains #girlgains #muscle #strength #motivation #muslce #booty #leanin15 #gymshark #gymsharkwomen #womensbest
A post shared by Carys Gray || Cardiff, UKüá¨üáß (@busybeefitness) on Feb 15, 2017 at 7:57am PST
In the photo on the left, Carys is wearing makeup and looking flawless. On the right, she's makeup-free, with red patches covering almost half of her face.
Carys has eczema, a chronic condition marked by patches of dry, itchy skin. Although she's been dealing with it her entire life, she was suffering from one of her worst facial flare-ups yet when she decided to take the photo pictured above. "I was close to tears, and I usually try and post about things I struggle with, so I decided to post about it," she says.
Advertisement - Continue Reading Below While her flare-ups can be unpredictable ‚Äî "the hardest part is finding out what is causing the flare up at that time and then eliminating it from my lifestyle," she says ‚Äî Carys noticed this one when she came out of the shower one morning after sleeping with traces of mascara on her lashes due to haphazard makeup removal.
Regardless of whether her skin is acting out, which can make her feel self-conscious, the condition affects Carys's daily life. She has to moisturize her entire body at least twice a day, use special products prescribed by her doctor, splurge on special makeup designed for sensitive skin, and be extra careful to avoid wearing clothes that can potentially irritate her. She's on a long-term steroid treatment to keep things under control and relies on a strong topical steroid treatment to sooth flare-ups, even though it can ultimately thin and damage her skin.
Although Carys knows that opening up about her eczema won't cure her condition, she was moved by the number of people who responded to her post as it's proof she's not the only one who struggles with this sort of thing. Her best advice to others going through it: "Try to embrace your insecurities. Don't allow your skin problem to define who you are or what you are doing with your life," she says. It's advice everyone should take to heart, before using filters to hide their imperfections from the world.
